I bought this game because I wanted to play another game like Long Live the Queen. If you also game here for this reason, *WARNING: Despite the title of the game, your daughter is NOT a princess!* You start the game as an average middle-class family, though [/spoiler] you can go up or down in wealth or social status by the end depending on your choices, stats, etc. As you can tell from my play time, I ended up liking this game even though it wasn't completely what I expected.
(I left the typo because I thought it was funny :D).

The Good
Art is so cute <3
Music is relaxing
There are a lot of endings, and you can do a lot of things in the game 

The Bad
OMG the run on sentences, THEY HURT MY EYES!
Grammar and spelling in the English translation are not great, but you can understand the translation (mostly ;-)
When exploring and catching horses, your character name is always "Rose" even if you changed it.
I found a bug where your game sometimes crashes when you try to catch horses. 

Tips: (hover over to reveal spoilers; these work as of Feb 22, 2024)
[/spoiler] If you get the perk for discounts at the shops in the charisma talent tree, you can get endless money, energy (action points) and stats by buying endless fertilizer from Jermaine for 112 gold and selling it back to him for 139 gold (for a profit of 27 gold each) when the shops have their yearly sale. You can maximize this gain by maxing all the farming and cooking talents also so that you can harvest more what and make more bread at a time for more AP more quickly. Unfortunately, the quickest way to buy fertilizer from Jermaine is buying 99 at once, which will give you so much favor with Jermaine that you are locked into marrying his son at the end =(. To avoid this, you can do the slower exploit of buying one fertilizer at a time, which won't increase your favor with him. 
[/spoiler] There is no crafting use for magic items you get while exploring; you just have to sell them to Jermaine.

Volcano Princess is a game that I genuinely cannot praise enough and needed to make a review on because it deserves every bit of praise possible. I'm surprised there's not really anything like it that came before, because the concept of getting to raise a child like this and help ensure you're raising them properly (and in a way that helps them achieve their goals) is so damn cool. The translation struggles from time to time with grammar, but otherwise it's perfectly fine and you can always tell what's being said and going on. And the chinese voice acting is very pleasant, they did a good job of making it feel very natural. Lastly, just the vibe of the game is really well done. There's so much clear care put into this game and I can't wait to dump a bunch more hours into it!

Loved this raising life sim. Multiple routes and endings/achievements. Challenging battles, characters to build relationships with. So much content and I got attached to multiple characters. Very much worth it <3

[STEAM DECK REVIEW]
The game plays well enough on the steam deck, but without controller support, your are forced to use a combo of the touchpad + R2 and touch screen. You can't use the touch screen alone most of the time due to the smaller, more fine text/button options making precise clicking difficult at times. And you can't use the right side touchpad + R2 button "mouseclick" for timed reaction events like some festival games due to the more precise, but ultimately slower movement of the cursor.

In short, this game is mainly meant for PC mouse and keyboard, but it is playable on the steam deck version of that with some getting used to.

[GAME REVIEW]
A great and wonderful addition to the Child Raising Sim Genre sparked by the original Princess Maker games. My one gripe about it is that its a little TOO easy. You can get what's supposed to be the most difficult and secret "True Ending" on the first try without guides. There is a kind of "roguelike" system that you can access after your first ending which will let you customize and add higher starting stats for your next run to make it easier to unlock other endings, but if your most difficult endings can be achieved without this, what's the point? The overarching gameplay itself in that regard needs better balancing.

However, you could also argue that this is what makes the lower or middle tier stat "difficulty" endings harder to achieve since it requires you to pay careful attention, making sure you don't raise your daughter's stats in certain areas too much. Despite that, it's still not anything that skill or math heavy. Its pretty much just occasionally looking at a stat and remembering your target number to get a specific ending. With the option to customize your stats on your second run and onwards, this can lead you to already having the desired stat amount and therefore not even needing to look at it for the rest of your run.

The Chinese to English translation isn't the best at times, but its generally understandable for the most part, so I don't have a real problem with it there.

Lastly, other than doing it because of your love and adoration for your utterly adorable daughter, I do think that the other endings are worth going for if you're a completionist like me or just enjoy seeing the story events or corresponding art. The gameplay between these different events and endings isn't very unique so that kills some of the replayability to it however. I found it more enjoyable to replay the game only after taking several week breaks in between play sessions so that I didn't get bored of it. That's not necessarily a bad thing since this is an offline single player game that you can put down or pick up at any time.

All in all, I'd give Volcano Princess a 7.5/10 and say its well worth the full price $11.

刚打完一周目，总体完成度很高，值这个钱，但多少有点过誉了……
[h2]优点：[/h2]
确实完成度很高，各方面都很完整，自由度也够高，内容足够多，可攻略对象都挺萌的。
雷贝莎很帅^3^
[h2]缺点：[/h2]
1.玩家只能扮演爸爸，很不爽。导致我基本没怎么听语音，每次被喊爸爸都一阵恶心。[spoiler]有人说保留妈妈隐藏身份设定的前提下没办法，[/spoiler]但玩家不能扮演姐姐/妈妈的好朋友/妈妈的女同对象吗，女儿都可以和女生结婚为什么我不可以……总之就是含爸浓度太高，时不时恶心我一下真的很烦。
2.剧情很一般，非常一般，随机剧情含量很少而且互不关联，总有一种“哦，触发到这个了啊”的感觉，主线看下来虽然能明白写了个啥但就是无感，很没劲。缺乏让人看进去的点和共情点。没劲。单人剧情除了[spoiler]雷贝莎真结局[/spoiler]以外也都一般般，合格是合格的但太普通了。不能和主线关联紧密一点吗？（目前走完了雷贝莎、妮娜、泽、那个忘了叫啥的在中央大街的穿一字肩的女人的好感剧情）
3.战斗后期很无聊很冗长，怪就那么几个，而且级别高了以后基本[spoiler]泽看情况石化+妮娜奶[/spoiler]就完全可以无脑打穿，却没有快速/自动战斗的方式，只能手搓，无聊到爆炸。
4.画风媚宅，连雷贝莎这样的战士都又白又瘦简直无法理解。我目前打的是女儿的猎人结局，都猎人了还要露成这样是要干嘛？要媚宅就媚到底也可以，让男角色多露一点平等点行不。很不爽。不知道你的女玩家占比多高吗= =

总之我应该还会再玩一周目吧，不知道后面体验能不能好点。

Okay, so I'm actually kind of in love with this game?

So it's not perfect, there are some strange translations and grammar errors here and there, but there is so much soul and hard work poured into this game.

Between the vast amounts of possible endings, choices and ways you can change your playthrough there is beautiful art, charming music and well thought through characters. Not just that but the lore and thought put into the world is top notch.

This isn't a play once and learn the full story game, but a take your time and explore.

the art and graphics are cute and i'm sure the story is cute too, but i frankly felt so stressed and lost during my first (and thus far only) playthrough that i couldn't pay much attention to it and had to quit. i feel like the game didn't explain the rules well enough and so i just kept failing and failing, and the story moves so quickly that any failure feels like a big deal and has rippling consequences on the rest of the story (you didn't use your days well enough because you don't know how to play, BOOM, your kid is a teen now and also you suck as a father!)

the game introduces JUST SO MANY things that you can do, doesn't explain how to do them really, doesn't offer any kind of priority system or proper incentive to try them out (i feel like having more straightforward quests and more time to really explore them would've been fun), and so you just get swamped with a million options that you keep failing at because you don't get how to do the 'mini games'.

it's kind of like stardew valley with the time crunch and low energy system, but instead of getting piecemeal information, quests to point you to what to do next so you can understand how to play the game properly/in a way that's fun and virtually endless time to try again and again, you get overwhelmed with information, you have no idea what to do next and when to do it, and it goes by SO QUICKLY that trying further feels like a waste of time.

i considered doing a new game and looking through guides online and stuff, but i don't really feel like the time and energy are worth it for a game of this kind, where it's meant to be a simple and cute time, so i'll probably just walk away (also, it'd feel like homework lol, i'm not the kind of person who wants to research for games, i just wanna play them and have a fun time, which very much didn't happen with this game). really sad though, i was looking forward to playing something similar to the mobile games i played as a kid without the annoying microtransactions and ads included. 

(it does seem like my experience with the game is in the minority, and while scrolling negative reviews i only really saw complaints about the translation (which i personally didn't mind too much, but i get why other people might), so maybe this kind of pacing and gameplay is normal for these games? who knows)
It makes sense that my first attempt would lead to the "commoner" ending... It's fate for me to be poor.

Volcano Princess is so cute and heartwarming! I love sitting back and relaxing when playing. All the characters are drawn so well. Once you complete your first run, there are end game rewards that help your next run through go smoother, quicker, and to reach higher 
 stats. I played with the Japanese VA, and all the voices fit each character well. The *only* gripe I have is the music used in the forest area on the map. In comparison to all the other lovely songs in their sound track, there is just something that doesn't sound right with the composition at the forest. I usually just turn off the sound if I am there for long. But otherwise, that's just a personal thing. I love everything else about Volcano Princess!  
I cant wait to try and collect all the achievements!

Edit: One other thing that I forgot to mention that I will put in a possible bug form in for is that when you save the game manually, your progress for that day/month/turn is not recorded, so once you reload that same save file- it brings you to the start of the day that you previously saved on. None of what you used your resources on will be recorded. 
Once I was aware of that I was able to be more conscience of when I saved and logged off, but it did surprise me at first.

This game is so so so good!!!!! It's totally filled the Princess Maker 2 shaped void in my heart. 

The art style is so lovely, and there's so much love put into all the illustrations that you'll come across while playing. It's the kind of game where you can feel that the creators loved the characters, too. The gameplay is also perfectly addicting and feels really good. It sticks faithfully to the formula that made Princess Maker so good, but I really enjoy everything that it adds as well, like being able to walk around the town during a turn. 

I think the world and the story are interesting, and I was genuinely surprised at the direction that one of the plotlines took. However, the English translation leaves something to be desired, and at times it can be difficult to parse what exactly is happening or being said. But even despite that, I adore this game so much!! It almost instantly cemented itself as a new favorite in my heart, and I know I'll keep playing for a long time to keep getting all the different endings.

also tip for new players: at the end of the game when she's about to go to her graduation ceremony, save the game so that you can go back to that save file and get every available ending for that play through.

This is actually my first time playing a "princess maker" type game. I saw the positive reviews and figured I would give it a try, but wow, I didn't think I would like it as much as I did. The gameplay doesn't ever really get too dull or boring and the visuals and artwork are pretty great. However, it does get terribly repetitive and sometimes tedious after your first few playthroughs and the game is quite long if you're not just rushing through it. This might discourage you from playing after your first or second playthroughs so the replayability factor is kinda low. I think that's more of a problem with the genre of the game rather than the game itself though. There's only so much you can do with life sims, you know? Otherwise, it's an amazing game. I love it. 

There's also been some negative reviews which complain about the "horrible English translation" but as of writing this review, the translation seems fine to me. Yes, there are some grammatical errors and other mistakes here and there but it's never bad to the point where you don't know or can't understand what's happening. I'm not sure where those reviews are coming from lol. It definitely doesn't warrant a negative review. 

On top of that, the price tag is very reasonable for the abundant amount of content you get in this game.

The game tries to do a lot at once and the transition is 'meh', but otherwise it is really good!

[h1] TLDR: [/h1]
Volcano Princess is a game that focuses on the relationship between a father and his daughter as they both grow and mature as individuals and as family members. There are lots of endings and even more things to do, but the pacing of this game is best designed for people who want to take their time and immerse themselves in its engaging plot and dynamic characters. It feels more like a story than anything, the only difference is that it is primarily driven by your choices. This has become one of my favorite games; I give it an easy 9/10. This game is worth your money and deserving of your time; but it realistically isn't for everyone. But with all that being said? Please buy this game. Please don't cheat yourself out of a great memory.


I initially typed out my whole review and it was so long and detailed, it cut itself off. So I actually made an entirely separate document to say everything that has to be said. But the important things to know if you don't want the full thing:

- The art, animation, and music is stellar. Like seriously impressive.

- The characters are a delight and very dimensional in motivations and personality.

- Game mechanics are fun and simple to understand.

- Emotionally impactful. LGBTQ+ friendly too if that makes a difference to your judgement of the game.

- The English translation is perfectly legible and understandable, but awkward at times. 

- I beat my first run in about 8.5 - 9 hours. Granted, I took my time. You can speed through in a third of that if you wanted. The replayablity is what forgives its short length for a run.

- If you're looking for replayability, I can imagine that unless you really like this game, want all the achievements, or you want to 100%, you really aren't going to want to keep going after your second or third run.

- Playing on Steam Deck technically works, but not as well as it could. Some awkward controls but technically runs fine, except for one thing. There's a portion of the game that softlocked my Steam Deck OLED, both game and system. The event is in the link to the full review.


Please look at my full review where I talk about the intricacies. It has spoiler protection that can be bypassed by just copying the text or highlighting it with your mouse. It won't take long and it's worth your time, just 7 pages of helpful and passionate review.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/10cdAuEQsgHMPfRISkEsz8aVZ2DgW2moANVBycbrdf4Y/edit?usp=sharing

Man, this is one of the 39583 games that shows that Steam really should introduce a midly recommended button.

This would be a very good game...  If it was in early acess.

Th entire game feels like it's an Alpha. A very playable alpha mind you, but an Alpha. But, most of the game's content feel shallow, or straight up unfinished. Which wouldn't be that big of a problem if this wasn't the type of game that you're expected to have multiple playthoughs, making the cracks be more apparent the more and more you play, making you getting better at it being very unrewarding. 

There are some horrible problems in tutorialization too, some games mechanics are explained differently than what they actually are, almost as if the dev changed how they worked but forgot to change the tutorial text.

Adn the most glaring issue: The translation. It's bad. Like, it's really bad. google translator/literal translation bad.  And given that this is a story driven game, it really hurts your ability appreciate the characters dialogue and their story. For example, there is a character that has difficult speaking. It took my second playthrough to realize that was on purpose and not the translation being bad. 

The translation is also very confusing for the gameplay itself. The same mechancs will be given two different names, sometimes three, making you have to guess what you're even doing.

Which is not to say the game is bad in everything, the art is absolutely gorgeous, there is hundreds of different of beautiful drawn images, there's dozens of endings, dozens of marriage endings, and the game feels engaging enough for the first playthrough, and you get a good attachment to your daughter as she grows up.

So... Yeah. a 6.5/10.

Ps: The dev team is like, 2 people for most of the stuff in it. Which is absolutely insane given the amount of things this game has, as shallow as they may feel. Hopefully with the amount of copies the game sold they can afford to hire a full time dev team, either for a sequel, or to make the current content feel more cohesive and replayable.

Also, for the love of god. I pray they hire a new translator/translation team. The current ones are either scamming the devs, or they are really, really, amateur.

edit: After 6 months of reflecting about this game I realized I was being too kind to it. And after 6 months, with no news on a translation update, or just a.... update to fix the issues regarding shallow or bugged mechanics, I cant on good mind recommend the game.

I hope to see improvements in the translation & grammar in the future as this game has incredible potential. I hope to see more from Egg Hatcher in the future.

我玩過美少女夢工厂系列，最喜歡的是美少女夢工廠2（因爲比較多匪夷所思的道具、衣物、隱藏的事物、比較有趣~遺憾是結局了沒有回憶畫廊之類的回看....），這個火山公主有種相似的復古畫風，游玩方面也是挺有趣的。

游玩性方面—比美少女夢工厂2 更多可玩性，街道有地圖，可以聊天、請教、玩牌、調整、送禮物、約會、種菜烹飪回復行動等等。玩完一輪結局后，有畫廊看回戰利品=成就感！（照片），角色也多（更多攻略對象？）比較可惜的是戰鬥方面。

戰鬥方面——過於呆板，只是按罷了？沒有招式畫面（愛神餐館的戰鬥就蠻好的），無法探索地圖……

For the new player.
GAMEPLAY : 4/5
The gameplay is just about clicking and manage your daughter's stamina, choose her studies, make her talk and built relationships with NPCs (that could lead to marriage by some characters or befriend with them and ask them to join your party), clear the dungeon (turn-based), and many more options to choose. 
You also choose for your personality as a father. Strict, Lovely, Kind, Wise, Adorable, Cruel (Why this??).
If you don't like clicking and choices choosing game. Pass this game. But if you love to read and learn about character growth. I super recommend this game.
REPLAYABILITY : 5/5
The replayable is quite large due to many routes, many romance, many ending jobs. 
ART STYLE : 5/5 
The style of art is Japanese-visual novel style. Every character design is great.
STORY : 4/5
Some of the story still conflict and there's plot hole.(But not much) 
CONTENT : 4/5
Some of the contents is the same with others. Clicking and clicking and choose the best choice.
Some content required too high status, so you can't do it in your first playthrough. 
DAUGHTER : lovable/5
No need to tell. My daughter must be happy.

OVERALL : Daughter/5 
Buy this game. It's worth your time and every penny.

Wonky translation and dialogue box errors are probably the most off-putting things about this game. Now, with that out of the way, overall it's a very cute, tamagochi-style game where you take care of your virtual daughter in order to bring her up as an outstanding member of the society (or not, it's up to you). Mine became astronomically rich on top of having two boyfriends at the same time, so I felt a great sense of accomplishment. You go girl. Everything is clear and manageable even without a guide thats usually mandatory to follow for these types of games, as well as being pleasantly light on creepy subtext. Not to say it's completely nonexistant, though, but nothing that destroys the sweet fluffy cuteness of the visuals.
At the same time, I'm always puzzled by how the player takes on the role of a father yet also you play as the daughter and then date all kinds of people as her.  Not to throw shade on fathers or anything, but I really wish you could pick between the parents' genders (I am aware that the girl's mother is already relevant to the plot, just make it work. somehow), like a cosmetic option which doesn't affect gameplay or overall plot.

There is soooo much content in this game, so many endings and characters, and I found it really enjoyable. The only issue is the poor English translations. It made understanding some of the dialogue kinda hard.
Great game

I enjoy the story, I enjoy the characters, and I enjoy the way you play the game. The only thing that is frustrating is that there are A LOT of bugs. I report them when the option pops up when I bring up the game again, but doing everything needed in a turn and ready to plan and then it crashes? Knowing I will have to start the turn all over again because it doesn't save at any time other than the beginning of each turn? It becomes frustrating. Obviously I haven't let it stop me for the most part as I am 31 hours in and will continue playing it when I'm less frustrated that I just wasted all that time to have it not save... 

But despite that little frustrated rant, this is a good game. Some typos in the English translation, but that has never bothered me in all the different otome and visual novel games I've played. I definitely recommend this game but just be wary. It doesn't crash enough to be extremely angry, but is something you should know going in.

Unironically, I loved this game so much. I've had a lot of fun playing this kind of genre of game that I normally wouldn't play, and it was an amazing choice to get this game. For its price too, there's so much replayability potential in this and that's great. Each character is fleshed out that you interact with and the art in this game is just ugh gorgeous. I also extremely loved such being able to take care of a daughter, and I got so emotionally attached to her. Because everyone is engaging and the amount of options/paths you can take, I'm definitely replaying this more after this review. Though I didn't care too much about the main storyline, it's nice to see they tried to add something there and I appreciate it. The translation is mostly there, but it didn't hinder my experience too much. The only thing I'd wish this game would do is make all the main romance characters fully voice acted because that'd just make the experience much more impactful and nice. I highly recommend this game, 9/10. Ze caught my eye instantly, Mona and Nina makes me smile, but Benson has my heart strings <3

At first I thought this game was just going to be a cheap, mobile type game. I didn't think there would be much to it and I just wanted it for the cute art. It was to my surprise that the game ended up being way more in depth than I could ever imagine. There are so many achievements (that you can work toward in the game itself), lots of mini games, many many different endings, and lots of paths to choose. There's even a talent system at the end of the game that rewards replaying the game!! This was such a pleasant surprise and very worth my $10. I could spend hours playing this game.

A great game and a lot fun, very reminiscent of Princess Maker 2 but a more modern take. I played ALOT of Princes Maker 2 and adored it so I was very excited to see a similar game release in modern times. Art is beautiful and the world much more fleshed out then the game it resembles. Also has much more in depth friendship system though I really wish there was more character events then there currently is. This game also has a longer play style then Princess Maker. 1 full playthrough took me about a full day or a estimated 7 hours which is a BIG difference from the quicker playthroughs that Princess Maker generally had. That is if your going for the bigger endings.

I must mention the translation for this game is a somewhat bad. Most of the time I can understand whats being said and happening but during the larger story reveal the bad translations made following far harder. I don't think its bad enough to drag the game down as I still enjoyed it a lot even with the errors but its something to be aware of. The beginning cutscene particularly is bad but it gets much better throughout the game in my opinion.

The story overall is alot of fun, though I feel a weird about the fact that she can end up with the adults or her own professors. But you don't have to unless your 100 percenting the game and the gameplay really is fun so I can let it go. Its easy to make sure this doesn't happen just be sure your chosen love interest has the most relationship points. Though if the others reach a certain level as well you may get a dejected letter from other characters in the ending, but that's easy enough to skip through. 

Would definitely recommend I'm already on my third play through and still having a blast. If you enjoy the Princess Maker series this is absolutely worth the price.

But my main complaints are:

-Your character can have romance endings with people you did not romance, sometimes for no apparent reason
-Without a guide, it was very hard to successfully get endings
It's a nice little world to live in and I'm sure if you take the time to get some of the cooler endings or get to the end of the forest that's interesting, but this game just wasn't for me. I liked it the first few runs but I probably won't play it again.

This game actually feels mechanically better and LOOKS better than actual 'Princess Maker' games. Art is gorgeous, and I REALLY appreciate that the game allows you to pick MULTIPLE endings, and has stat decrease items to achieve even more endings in one save. I loved the story! It was very cute despite some of the flaws I saw in it's narrative.

So are there any problems? Yes. 

1) The English translation is NOT good. Sometimes I can barely understand what was happening. In fact, I didn't even know time looping was a thing until someone on a forum mentioned it to me. The English translation doesn't read like real people are speaking. As another example; I had difficulty telling whether Kenneth could REALLY not speak well, or if it was just the translation struggling to portray someone socially awkward. The translation NEEDS to be redone at some point, because there exist many english speakers who refuse to buy this game because the translation is so bad. 

2) The plot has some holes because the protagonist (your daughter) is only an observing party until the very end of the game. You see, aside from the fathers memories.... the plot goes on without the player almost entirely in the background. And infact, one could argue that the plot is more about the mother, father and three lords... Not the daughter. And this is a problem; because there is a specific plot point concerning her father... where the daughter SHOULD'VE been actively searching for a cure, but never did. She instead just keeps it a secret, and lets the three lords figure it out themselves while she lived life completely normally. And this caused narrative problems in the story, as certain plot points remain unclear which would've otherwise made sense if the daughter was actually involved in the plot.

3) I loved the characters, they just didn't have enough involvement in the story for me to feel much attachment. Other than the lords, only Nina is the only other reoccurring character in the plot. Every other character fundamentally doesn't matter, as they are not at all involved in the story and their events are completely optional.
Characters such as Kenneth, Hackett and Ze had a LOT of potential for additional story points; but that potential is never actually explored or realised in the game.

----

In summary: LOVE THIS GAME! It's an upgrade over the 'Princess Maker series' despite its flaws. However, I would like to someday see a better english translation, and perhaps some DLC concerning characters like Kenneth, Ze and Hackett. I feel like having them be the individual protagonist of their own mini episode would flesh out and get players more attached to their characters.

If this devloper makes any future games, I hope that that they make the daughter more involved in the plot. And I hope for some more fantasy characters(Let us marry a demon lord!) and more fantasy endings. As those are my favourite elements in Gainax's princess maker series.

If I would describe this game, it's an spiritual successor to the legendary Princess Maker series and I love Princess Maker. I played PM 2, 3 and 5 for the most part, with PM3 being my most favorite and PM2 not far behind.

You played as "Wood" the father. The end game is to raise your daughter "Rose", guide her to various decision and watch her as she slowly transition from child to adulthood. You raising your daughter by balancing the resource, mostly Money and Action Point, to allocate your daughter stats, relationship with NPC, romancing marriage candidates both boys and girls, juggling your daughter moods, choosing which class she goes, horse racing, cooking, fight street thug, fight monster, fight demon, fight your friend, fight god, play dress up, meet important people, play dice, went acting, do alchemy, do math, and etc.... 

With these much variety ways (side gameplay) of raising your daughter, the good news here is you won't have to deal with these all at once. The game did a pretty good job introducing and getting used to them as the time goes.

At it's core, Volcano Princess is a visual novel with a couple of mini games littered in between. Whatever decision you pick will slow affect your virtual daughter over the course of 8-12 hrs and where she will ended up. The game has many replayability. Many endings and loads of save slot at your disposal. RNG does influence the result from time to time. Save scumming can be an option for completionist. But I would recommend to go blind and try many mechanic this tiny game has to offer for the first run, then you can start doing min-maxing later.

Voice acting is great, with both original Chinese and recently Japanese. Despite mostly limited to important sentence and your daughter. I'm not proficient at both language so I might be wrong, but I can feels the character well. The music well suited the game theme, usually clam and serene with an alright action music when things get heated in fight. The art is real good and consistence through most game some really beg to have a thumbnail or wallpaper. The mugshot and chibi icon really cute. Although, I kinda do wish all the NPC, beside Nina, can have more art or sprite as a children to grow along with the daughter to create some sense of time passing, otherwise everyone just look static (either teenager and adult) through out the whole game.

Unlike Princess Maker, however, Volcano Princess is safe for all devoted christian and all age which ever decision you may choose. :)

To end the review, I overall gave this game 8/10. The only complain is that I felt the "True Ending" is a bit underwhelming, coming from me a PM fans, the way of achieving wise. And with 8-12 hrs per game is about OK, I do prefer a more arcade feels 3-5 hrs of PM 2 and 3 of a full play through (I'm looking at you PM5... I'm not a very save scummy person when it comes to this kind of game, but with a realistic pacing of 40+ hrs per playthough with many many possible ending!!? I know you would love to be the most comprehensive raising daughter game ever but come on now!). 

Some may complain about the english translation quality. While, yes, it does have some issues, mostly to do with conveying the emotion (lost in translation?). The text clipped off the textbox from time to time. I personally found the English does it job for the most part. They honestly did a much better job than CFK's Princess Maker half-arse translation, which sometimes do affect the game play in significant way. But here what we have is perfectly fine for the most part.

Other than that, this game is a blast to go through. It makes you care and anticipate whatever in game NPC interaction can makes you overall feels good and real relax game. I'm happy for what I'm getting and a kind of game I can casually come back from time to time. :)
I hope they release a DLC or something because I want to play more of this game.

So far, very cute, fun, and occasionally quite touching,game with a good amount of variety.  You play as a father raising a young daughter - but she quickly goes from a cute youngster to a teenager with a lot of life lessons to learn. I like the variety of activities and mini-games you can play, which mix-up the game play a bit. Some of them are more fun than others. It's a little annoying that "dueling" and "debating" are completely input free after selecting them and the text scrolls past too fast to read, and the horse beauty pageant minigame is pretty tedious. On the other hand, exploring and dungeon-crawling are so fun it's hard to not splurge all your  action points in one place and keep a focus on the rest of the game. There are a LOT of potential love interests, but so far all the romance storylines have been sweet and wholesome. The game does contain some dark twists, depending on the path you take, but so far nothing has come across as problematic - just evil people doing evil stuff that the game KNOWS is evil stuff and doesn't get graphic with. 

It does take a relatively long time to complete a playthrough and the saving system means it's harder to effectively branch playthroughs. I also wish there were options to skip through cutscenes you've already seen. I don't want to hear the backstories of every person I befriended for the purposes of bashing monsters every single time I play. 

Overall, a very fun game I look forward to completely exploring!

So many good things about this game. It has a pretty good difficulty balance if you're looking to earn the best endings (made easier with a ng+ save file) and the story is pretty intriguing. I've also liked all the casts and romanced characters from both teams. So much replayability especially since there's a lot of good characters to date and endings to achieve. My only gripe though is that [spoiler] Lebsa is your sister and has so many complications to her character where she would have worked much better even without them - that and I feel bad about not saving her in literally every run but her romance paths - [/spoiler] but even though I say that, at the time of writing, I still married her. 100% would do it again too.

Despite some (okay a fair amount) of translation issues, this is a very cute game with some fun character interactions and endings. 
Like a lot of child raising simulators, there are some funny moments where the romance and career endings seem to contradict each other, and while trying to hunt down some of the more basic endings, I discovered the romance options have hidden requirements to trigger their events. 
But! Those are largely my only complaints, I replayed this game probably a dozen or more times and rarely got bored, I really like the combat, and there's a fun hack available to get infinite energy/money in one of the steam comments, if you're really struggling that I chanced upon my sixth or seventh go. It's a very fun game, in my opinion!

As an avid xianxia/wuxia web novel reader I absolutely love this game! I feel like you get so many choices to raise your daughter to become essentially anything which is nice since a lot of games have multiple endings but not as many as this game. She can be a concubine, a goddess, demon queen, or just straight up unemployed it all depends on how you raise her. There are probably 100+ endings and that isn't including the romantic type. You get to decide her love life and who she marries. One woman not enough for you? Marry two! Two guys not enough for you? Marry five! The art is sublime for each ending and each character has their own personality traits. Looking for that tsundere made just for you? Look no longer! Maybe you want someone who makes YOU their main character in novels. Or that playboy that stops chasing women because he fell for you. There is even a woman that points out how annoying stories can get when the female protagonist is treated like garbage but ends up saving everyone in the end (which happens in a lot of female lead wuxia/xianxia novels).  This game has it all and so much more. 

P.S Hackett and Ze are the best ending ;) both hot strong men!

When I first decided to buy this game, I was a bit hesitant for the translation issue that was noted in some of the previous reviews thinking that it would be bad. Well, after playing for 30+ hours I do say that it could have been better, but honestly the issue wasn't bad enough for me to ruin the game and I enjoyed it. It has variety of things to do which are fun and interesting, a whole array of possible career, story, and romance (IT HAS HAREM AND REVERSE HAREM ENDING?! I'm sold!) endings which is a requirement for a good CYOA/Simulation game, and a decent story plot (a bit of inconsistency at the conclusion but oh well).

Do note that while the game is kind in offering wide-range of possibilities, this game is pretty rigid on the requirement of getting it so if you are a game completionist then please beware. Otherwise, this game is a great way to spend your time by nurturing and watching your virtual daughter grow up and handle their future.

This is such a satisfying game! I was looking for a [b]Princess Maker[/b]-type game for a while and discovered this four months ago. I started playing it then and finished my first playthrough within two days. 

This is a very detailed game. There is a good variety of NPCs and I like the interactions with them, whether it's the ones you can befriend or the background ones that just appear every once in a while to make some amusing, disturbing, or mysterious comments. There is such good depth to the conversations that you get a different script when you talk with the NPC on a different day. Some of them comment on certain items in your inventory and changes in your attributes or fame, while some react to different outfits! 

An interesting aspect of this game is how it approaches career endings. It's trickier to find the mediocre ones. I enjoyed the challenge of going for them! With that in mind, I still very much recommend this to any achievement hunters. Though some achievements could be trickier, I found that they are definitely achievable. I found it more difficult to complete the [b]Gallery[/b] and [b]Collection Room[/b] because many of them rely on chance and thus require reloads unless you have the patience and time to go through multiple playthroughs to see if they would trigger without reloading. 

Some things that could use improvement in the game are fixing the items and achievements that are labelled wrongly and fixing the wrong descriptions for some of the goals and achievements in the game. You can see the item label issue with some of the paintings whose labels don't match what is depicted. Achievements with the wrong label and description include [b]Turn and Retreat[/b] and [b]Ordinary Father[/b]. [i](Check [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/1669980/discussions/0/3809531491903080075/]this discussion[/url] for tips on the latter.)[/i] There is also some awkwardness in the dialogue due to the English translation, but I honestly did not mind and found some of them humorous. 

Overall, I highly recommend this game for casual players, achievement hunters, and completionists who enjoy raising simulator games. I purchased this game with a 15% discount (9.34 USD) but I think this game is worth its full price or perhaps even more. This has a lot of replay value since you need three playthroughs to work with the three different Knight Paths. It took me five playthroughs to get everything I wanted in the game. Even for just my first playthrough which took me 13 hours, I think it was a good purchase with what I paid and how long I played the game.

Translation is off with spelling and grammar issues, but the concept is pretty different from all the life sim RPGs. The art is nice overall, I really like the different characters. Daughter father interactions are cute, romancing characters was hard to understand at first; was pretty smooth after getting the hang of it. I would play it again to try other routes, but I am not sure if I can get past the weak story line and grammar mistakes.

A cute and relaxing game. For a life sim, it have min-maxing aspects which could get repetitive for a while, especially if we want try to get all the endings. Despite the rough translation and some bugs (such as freeze when catching animals for the first time), I really enjoyed Volcano Princess from the beginning til the end.

If you are a person who loves Princess Maker or Long Live The Queen: you will absolutely adore this game, and will probably become so entranced you sink hours and hours of your life into this. It is peak Raising Sim. I adored it. 

Yes, the translation is very choppy - that's an unfortunate truth. But I managed to adjust pretty early on. The art style is gorgeous, the CGs are plentiful, and the daughter is loveable. What else can you want?

Volcano Princess is an experience I certainly wont forget.

That being said, it was not perfect.

Pros:

Music - The music in Volcano Princess is something I'm certainly going to be hunting for on streaming services!

Characters - All the characters are well written and diverse, making them all fun to talk to.

Art - Volcano Princess's art is... stunning. Especially the cut scene art.

Story - I've only played through once, but the story left me longing for more. (although it is a NG+ game)

Cons:

English Translations - The English translations for Volcano Princess are spotty, with some parts being much worse than the others. However, it was always clear what was trying to be said!

A little repetitive - Volcano Princess can be a little grindy, but I don't think this is one of its major faults. It makes up for it through the story and I didn't even fully use the battle mechanism's that come with leveling up strength.


In the end, Volcano Princess is a game I will hold close to my heart. Seeing my Lillia grow up was a wonderful experience and I both dreaded and longed for the end. If you're looking for a game to calm yourself down and cool off, this is the perfect game for it. The art, music, and story make it easily one of my favorite games here on Steam. In my opinion, it was worth every cent.

10/10. Wonderful experience. Would 100% play again.

[i]Volcano Princess[/i] is a very endearing life sim title. To echo the actual store page description, the player assumes the role of the father of the lovely little angel Rose (I went with the default given name in my first playthrough) and by his actions [spoiler](and her own later on in life)[/spoiler], will shape what kind of woman she grows into come adulthood. There are actually a fair number of endings present, which I will gloss on slightly a bit later.

[h3]PROS:[/h3]
+ The simplicity of [i]starting[/i]. The game begins fairly easily, with mechanics being easy to understand - it’s mostly point-and-click throughout. However, the depth of Volcano Princess lies with all the various ways of growing Basic and Core attributes, developing Natural Skills and relationships with the various townspeople, and even acquiring hidden conditions (called “Darkness”) when nurturing Rose. Essentially, every action taken is factored into how the ending will turn out. Because of how free the player is in deciding their virtual daughter’s future, Rose can actually become either a very good, or very bad person. Though, why would you ever want the latter, goodness gracious. [b]EDIT (26.11.21):[/b] It is a very easy game to get into, and does well to draw you in after just a short while.

+ The gorgeous artwork is one of the game’s biggest draws. Very adorable and lovely, and the various scenes spaced throughout the main and relationship stories are nicely done too.

+ At the start of each day, the player is able to interact with Rose before she begins her daily adventures, with the frequency increasing as she matures. In fact, she is actually fully voiced for all these interactions. As of writing this, there are currently choices for either Japanese or Chinese voices. [b]EDIT (26.11.21):[/b] It really helps immerse and endear the player to the game, listening to the sweet voice of their daughter each morning.

+ The music is sweet. As expected of a game of this genre, it is calming, with fantasy tones befitting the setting. The various ambience presented is fairly soothing and relaxing to listen to on loop, in some areas.

+ Developing relationships will influence the end game. Not simply who her future spouse(s) will be, but if I’m not mistaken, it is also factored into what sort of career Rose will have. There exists a decent range of interesting characters from various tropes whom Rose can interact with and befriend. Some offer her jobs, others sell her clothing or equipment, and of course there are also those who can be recruited to join her party for explorations.

+ The English translation is fairly good, with only minor inaccuracies in certain dialogues. And it’s not all incorrect per se either, just, not the most impactful to use at times.

+ [b]EDIT (26.11.21):[/b] Newly added this. There is a mechanic unlocked after completing your first playthrough which aids in speeding up future runs. At the games conclusion, you are given an amount of Firestone (amount is dependent on how well you met the goals previously), which can be used to boost Rose's starting attributes, skills, and relationships in future games. Thus, reducing some amount of the early game grind.

[h3]NEUTRALS:[/h3]
+/- There isn’t much explanation of an overall, overarching story currently, despite it being sort of hinted at in the prologue, and here and there throughout the game’s progress. While there are pieces of lore fillers, it currently lacks a cohesive structure. This could be a feature expanded upon by the developers, on a later date. Or even be the premise for a second title in the series? I hope so, either way.

+/- There is a simple combat system in place which is only available when one chooses the Explore option while at the Forgotten Valley. Fairly straightforward and not tedious. It is a direct turn-based system, where Rose's party is allocated a certain amount of AP each turn. She would have to choose which skills to use, and where to target them, each with various effects and cooldowns. Successfully managing AP and building a versatile party composition is necessary to emerge victorious in explorations. Successfully completing quests will advance Rose’s Knight Career, something which gets introduced pretty early in the story, and can influence the ending as well. [b]EDIT (26.11.21):[/b] Move this to a neutral, as the very minimalist system may either serve to interest or disinterest the player, depending on their personal preference. And provided some additional explanation about the combat system.

+/- If you are a completionist, then you will be playing this game for a long, long while, considering the vast multitude of endings. However, if you’re the sort to enjoy that, or just adore the simple fact of raising a child like Rose, then I suppose this is actually a very big [b]PRO[/b] instead. [b]EDIT (26.11.21):[/b] Move this to a neutral.

[h3]CONS:[/h3]
- None thus far. At least, in my subjective opinion.

[h2]VERDICT:[/h2]
A very wholesome take on the life sim genre, Volcano Princess will charm you with its lovely main character and delightful setting. You’ll be relaxing and spending quite a bit of time exploring the various ways to go about parenting darling Rose. Will you be an awesome father or a lame dad? And at the end, you might even shed some genuine tears once she's all grown up.
one of the most tender and cute games I've played 10/10

I've really enjoyed the raising sim genre since playing Princess Maker 2 back in the heyday of DOS games. I've only found a couple since that really improved upon the genre or added anything noteworthy. The other before Volcano Princess being Long Live the Queen. VP is a breath of fresh air in a rather stagnant genre of niche games. The game play is comfortably familiar while not being afraid to discard a few tired systems and tropes. The art is lovely, the lore extensive and interesting, the story is intriguing, and the potential endings plentiful. I'm so glad I came across this game and definitely see myself coming back to this fun and cozy title for years to come.

Today, I, your trusty French fry game critic, am here to share my crispy insights on the scorching-hot sensation that is "Volcano Princess". Just like a perfectly golden batch of fries, this game has left me sizzling with excitement.

First things first, let's talk about the flavor of the game – and oh la la, it's a spicy one! From the moment I dipped my digital self into the molten world of Volcano Princess, I was greeted by a visually stunning landscape that's as enticing as a golden, crispy exterior. The graphics are so hot, they're practically on fire, and the attention to detail is as meticulous as the seasoning on a fine plate of French fries.

Now, let's talk about gameplay – the heart and soul of any game, just like salt is to a French fry. Volcano Princess serves up a delectable blend of platforming and puzzle-solving that keeps you coming back for more. The controls are as smooth as the creamiest ketchup, making it easy for players of all skill levels to enjoy the adventure.

The narrative is the secret sauce that ties everything together. The story unfolds with the grace of a perfectly executed saute, keeping players engaged and eager to discover what lies beyond the next fiery ridge. The characters are as diverse and flavorful as a basket of assorted fries – each with their own unique charm and backstory that adds layers to the overall experience.

The soundtrack deserves a special mention, much like the seasoning on a truffle oil-infused parmesan fry. The music complements the game like a fine wine pairing, enhancing the immersive feel of the volcanic world. It's a symphony of sizzles and pops that adds a dash of excitement to every step of the adventure.

And let's not forget the replay value – a crucial factor, just like the desire for a second helping of fries. With hidden secrets, multiple endings, and a variety of gameplay styles, Volcano Princess ensures that players will be coming back for seconds, thirds, and more.

In conclusion, Volcano Princess is a feast for the senses, much like a plate of perfectly seasoned French fries. It's a game that not only satisfies the craving for a spicy adventure but also leaves you wanting more. So, grab your digital ketchup, dive into the molten world, and enjoy the crunchy goodness that is Volcano Princess! 🍟✨

This game is amazing!
Found it while browsing through games, Saw that the reviews were overwhelmingly positive... game was pretty cheap so decided to give it a go. So glad i did! So much love and passion has been put into this hidden gem. 19 hours of gameplay in 2 days hehe.

The gameplay: Is very simple yet still has depth to it with management. Interacting with other people in the world and befriending them by talking, gifting and going on friendly dates with them. Each character has there own story and are fleshed out very well. There are horse riding events to do, Theatre, Bathhouse and a dice mini game. There is a dungeon/adventure part of the game that involves combat which has a bit of strategy involved to survive and get the best rewards/fame. There is kind of a NG+ feature once you complete it for the 1st time. So when starting a new game (fresh run) you can boost some of your stats for that run.

The Graphics: The artstyle is very beautiful and well coloured. Lots of CG's to unlock and view (Once you complete the game once) Not many animated scenes but not really necessary imo. 

Verdict: This game was quite amazing. Nice slice of life sim that will put a smile on your face. 19 hours for my 1st playthrough and looking forward to starting another for more achievements. At full price (It's not that expensive anyways) it's so worth it <3

Indulging in this serene and therapeutic gaming experience, I found myself immersed in a captivating daughter-raising simulation. The game's enchanting art style boasts an undeniable cuteness factor. The music also creates a cozy ambiance that enhances the overall experience.

The stat-raising system was easily understandable. The game's intricate web of outcomes and multiple endings provides satisfying unpredictability. The prospect of exploring various paths and witnessing diverse conclusions makes the game inherently replayable.

However, there was a single drawback: the absence of Steam sync. Transitioning between PCs became a tad frustrating, as my progress didn't seamlessly carry over.

In conclusion, I wholeheartedly recommend this gem to fellow gamers seeking a delightful blend of relaxation, charm, and replayability. It's a whimsical journey worth embarking on, with its endearing visuals, soothing music, and the joy of shaping your own unique narrative within the game.

Volcano Princess is a lovely game. Raising your daughter and accidentally made her a war criminal.

Though the first play is rough as spreading resources evenly is quite the challenge and best to focus on one resources to fulfil a goal. There's a lot packed in here. If you enjoyed Long Live the Queen, I think you'd like this too. (Also, as a bonus: the game contains options for f/f relationships and polyamory!)

[h1]Volcano Princess Review[/h1]

    If you buy this game you will be able to enjoy it for hours provided you do not get burnt out from the repetitiveness. Your goal in the game is to raise/guide your daughter until she is an adult. Making her study/engage in different activities will influence her attributes. A different combination of attributes or level of these attributes will determine her adult life. Every day make sure you plan what you want to do to make her the happiest (or not)! There seems to be not only many different endings but also different romance pairing endings depending on how your daughter’s attributes are built(can romance both boy and girl and poly ending). There are also many items you can unlock after beating the game. There is a gallery with a collection just 100% this game will take a lot of hours. This leaves you with many hours of enjoyment getting your money back. However this can lead to burnt out. The relative structure of each playthrough and some events are fixed, what will be different is the different way you want to guide your daughter. Do you want her to be more combat focused? Or maybe guide her to be a lady? Do this by choosing different knight paths at the beginning of her school years and choosing different activities. Players who play VNs, or other life sim type games or games with life sims aspects (persona, fire emblem three houses) are familiar with this repetition but can get tiring if played for too long. I often felt myself going onto autopilot when playing for a long session forgetting that even though I was focused on trying to complete one goal I was ignoring the other important stats. I would advise you to take a break. (also thank God for the skip button for multiple playthroughs!!) 
   The translation from chinese to english is really not the best but playable. You can definitely tell it was translated literally from chinese at some places. You can get the general idea of the main story and what the characters are saying. Lore from NPC or friendship candidates events will give more background into the setting. The events are nice and some are cuter/have a more romantic undertone than the others. You do feel bad when high friendship characters send you a sad letter when you pick another person over them to marry. Even though it took a lot to process what was happening in the true story due to the unclear translation I can get the idea but I am still a little confused by it but I do not think this game is played for the main story anyways.  Before when you start there is little tutorial text you can read and after there are little question marks you can mouse over if you do not understand some parts of the gameplay or stats but this game does not handhold you. I liked being able to play the game/figure out how the game works for me.
You might also need a walkthrough to get all the endings or if you beat the game once the archive will tell you what stats are needed to unlock that career path. I would advise you to use the note feature on the steam overlay and write down which career path you are aiming for and the requirements.

[b]CREEPY DAD SECTION?[/b]
Those who are wary about playing as a Dad well once your daughter turns to a teen I believe you are playing as both characters the Dad and the daughter. Especially during the in town segments you are playing as the daughter. (I think we are the daughter because the Dad does not know the daughter’s friends even if we give her pocket money it disappears from the UI…). So I like the idea that we are guiding the daughter now instead of raising her. She is free to choose her own path, the Dad is not forcing her. I did not feel creepy at all at being a Dad character and felt the daughter was more self insert than the Dad. Secondly, the Dad really loves the Mom from what I can understand from the true ending and the home part of the end game bonuses section. The game did not influence me at all to be a real Dad except maybe at the end a little at the end XI JINPING SORRY!

[b]Conclusion[/b] 
Volcano Princess is a good game that is worth the price for the time you can play. While this game can have a lot of repetition there is a lot of replay value with the different career paths and knight path you can choose and different stat routes. If the English translation was professionally proficient (this is something that can change, hopefully fixed in the future!), I could see this game becoming bigger in the West with streamers. Buy this game if you like life sims with many different endings and things to unlock, good art and a lot of soul and heart put into it!
I bought this on sale but it's totally worth full price. You can see the effort and love that went into it

This is a very cute and fun game.

I was very engrossed in min-maxing every month like crazy in order to raise the most powerful daughter possible (I saved scummed a lot for horses, winter alchemy and master classes).

The dark play-through hurt me in the feels a bit, but I did it to raise the Demon Queen!

The NG+ play-through is hilarious once you have the bonuses, your daughter is born OP.

Certainly, the translation was a bit rough in some places, some systems are clearly incomplete and some things were obtuse, but I had a lot of fun with the game. It was very cute and heartwarming.

 I also believe that some achievements were broken, so I won't go for 100%, but it's not a big deal to me.

You might be tempted to ignore this one because the translation is really bad in places -- in fact, there's a hilariously immersion-breaking mistake right at the end that gets repeated over and over in the last fifteen minutes of play.

But if you can look beyond that, there's a surprisingly deep story hidden here that goes well beyond the standard "life milestones and daddy feelings" that you can get from any daughter-raising sim. Likewise, some of the interactions you can have with other villagers as you get to know them are genuinely touching.

It might not seem like much is going on at first, but if you know the genre tropes and start following them early, you can get the true ending in the first playthrough (that said, the true ending is probably even better with a certain romance path which might not be obvious.)

Some of the game's systems fall short for me (certain special event mini-games are a good idea but not great execution) but all in all I was pleasantly surprised at how this game breathes new life into a framework that's been done so many times, even the recent Princess Maker games are falling flat.

If you like this kind of game, odds are good you'll love Volcano Princess.

This game is amazing! Went on a spree for an entire week, and just one play-through if you're really into it can take hours! This game is amazing, the stories can be so fulfilling, and the options for love interests are amazing!

I love this game, I hope people come to think of it as a classic of the fantasy life-sim genre like Princess Maker or Cute Knight.

There's plenty to do, the writing is enjoyable, and the art is beautiful.

Like the original English release of Princess Maker, the translation is occasionally charmingly wobbly, but I always understood what it was trying to say - it's mostly some characters and places having a few variant spellings of their names (e.g. Lon/Ron, Alan/Ellen).

If you're an ending collector like me, the game helpfully lets you pick from the best ending of each "type" you qualify for, which is a great quality of life feature. Maybe my daughter does want to spend her entire childhood fighting monsters and then retire to become an amateur actress. The 35 hours I've clocked at the moment is four "full" runs of the game, plus some reloading to see different ending variations.

This game is one of those "one more turn" genre. Once you start raising the daughter and you cannot stop thinking about her all the time and the game is worth re-playable.
The story is so heart-warming and the art is so lovely. Every characters have their own interesting background and uniqueness even the side characters.
10/10 would raise my daughter again to collect all achievements.

I'm going to start out and say that this game can be buggy as fuck. But when you're NOT dealing with that, it's really fun! It's very reminiscent of the princess maker games, except it has a bit more depth than that. The translation has a few areas where it definitely could use some work, but I think the original game was in Korean idk though. Either way! I really enjoy the game and there's a TON of different endings that you can get. Very fun if you can get past the bugs and translation.

The translation could use a lot of work and there are some interesting glitches, exploits, and crashes (going for a horse as soon as the option becomes available to you might freeze the game). Some things don't make sense until you experience them (like the MC aging up twice in a year).
Despite its flaws its a very heartwarming game. This is the first growing up sim like this that I've played where you take the role of the parent directly, and it gives the whole thing a lot of heart. I felt like I could tear up a little when she came of age for the first time. I'm looking forward to future fixes. I've only completed the game once so far, but I know I'll be saying the same thing about it when I've come out of my completionist trance.

I wouldn't recommend if you can't look past these problems.

The translation has a lot of flaws but that doesn't detract from how incredibly cute and heartwarming this game can be. The only other game in this genre I've played is Long Live the Queen, and this game seems to have much lower stakes since (as far as I can tell from my first run) there are no deaths/failure states like in Queen. That's not a point for or against Volcano Princess, but it makes this game incredibly relaxed and calming to play.

There also seems to be an insane amount of ways that you can raise this kid, and none of them are bad paths to take, so it seems to have a lot of replayability.

If you like the genre this seems like a contender for the best game, and even if you aren't into the genre this game is the cutest thing I've played in years.

very sweet game, the art is beautiful, the npcs feel alive, lots of great romancing options and your decisions feel like they really matter, and not just in the sense of "pick these dialogue options to get the good ending", but the day-to-day actions that your daughter takes, the way you speak to your daughter, truly feel like they shape the person your daughter is becoming. It feels organic, and it has heart.

If you like stat raising life sims, this is definitely for you.  The English localization is...not great, but there's still a lot of charm here.  While I never really played Princess Maker, I did put in a lot of hours with Long Live the Queen, and it definitely scratches that itch and then some.  There's plenty to do during your four 'season years'; you can explore the forest (combat), go on dates with your friends, part-time work...and a lot of more.  The game ends at age 18 with the coming of age ceremony, and you find out what kind of daughter you've raised.  (My first run I went for wisdom.  She became a politician. ...if only that were true in real life...)

The only real complaint I have is, again, the translation.  It makes things a little confusing sometimes with the wording.  All in all, though, this is a wonderful game that is so wholesome your teeth will rot.

Simple, light-hearted, lovable gem.

I really enjoyed Long Live the Queen and other raising sims, but when I think on my nostalgia for Princess Maker 2, this Volcano Princess is definitely the most faithful AND feature-rich of them all, with extra bonus cuteness. Acting, horse racing, math minigames, cooking, gifting, combat, conversations with beautiful characters, geez, it's really impressive how much is stuffed in this little package, and all in a lovingly made, relatively rich world. The English translation is pretty hilariously awful in some moments, but it mostly works. A very relaxing and cute game. There are so many ways to raise the daughter and so many things to do in volcanic country, that it's overwhelming. She can turn into a criminal or a queen, depending on your choices. She can romance anyone, even from the same sex, as well as have polygamous relationships. The game is full of choices, content, and heart.

Unfortunately, there are some significant flaws in the game. The biggest of these (and the cause of a lot of issues) is the not-so-good translation of the game. It can cause misunderstandings about the gameplay instructions, make the dialogue feel uninteresting (which can make the game feel a bit draggy), and it makes the game feel very rough around the edges. Due to a lot of mistranslated text, some mechanics (like the dice game) are impossible to understand. 

If you want to play a wholesome game with a lot of great content, art, mechanics, and choices (and dialogue), this will fit perfectly. It is very playable even with the bad translation, it just keeps the game from being a masterpiece.

This is such a cute and captivating game. The artworks is fantastic and the music is so sweet and romantic. If there is one consistent thing that is bothering me, it is the English translation. There are so many grammar and spelling errors, it is hard to read, sometimes. Also, some situations call for you to choose between "ignore him" or "endure" and I don't think the game makers knew what those words meant for that situation. 

There is a time when a character who doesn't know how to write, sends you a letter expressing their feelings. When I first read it, I immediately thought, "oh man, this game's translation is getting worse," until they revealed in the letter that they couldn't write. The point: I didn't think the game was actually trying to portray an illiterate character. This is because the game has many poor English translations throughout that it takes you out of the game so much you find yourself coping with it more than you think. 

If there is some way to spend some of the revenue this game made to get a real English translator to redo the script, this would go a long way to make this game long remembered for fans... Especially those that remember Princess Maker, which had a wonderful translation.

This has quickly become my favorite game of this year.  While Volcano Princess is a small game in literal storage size, it's a huge feast of wholesomeness and enjoyment.  The game is all about min-maxing your daughter as her sole parent and watching her progress as she grows up.  It's such a simple concept done [i]so well[/i].  Egg Hatcher (devs) should be proud of this outstanding game.

As for pros and cons
+ A bit of everything; combat, intellect, romance, sorcery...
+ The art is pleasing to the eye, and there's no shortage of art to discover.
+ A generally like-able character set.  I couldn't bring myself to dislike any of the characters. [spoiler]Hacket and Ze have their issues, but still likeable[/spoiler]
+ Significant, widespread depth: Volcano Princess isn't the best at anything it does, but it's the best at combining all of them into a single game.
+ Quality of Life controls, so you aren't trapped reading the same dialogue over and over.
+ Each of the three main paths for the game do actually feel different when replaying.  Going for a charisma build is quite a bit different than brute forcing via a strength build.
+ Entertaining minigames and interesting "challenge-sequences", with a lot of flavor text to help flesh out what are essentially stat-checks.
+++ Incredibly wholesome father-daughter moments.  Many parts genuinely had me smiling out of happiness.
- The English Translation could use some proofreading by a native English-speaker.  Not really that bad.
- Some mechanics could use better explanation, such as "fame", which can be freely spent at the church without damaging ending potentials (not 100% on this, please comment if I am incorrect).
- Horse crash.  The first time you open the menu to catch a horse, the game crashes.  This should be an easily preventable issue, and had me stay away from the game for a while after... before coming back.
- Exploitable/missing mechanics.  Magic materials are pointless, sell them to the smith for extra cash.  [spoiler]Food and fertilizer are stupid powerful, need a cooldown on purchases[/spoiler]
-? Not much in terms of negative outcomes, only a handful that can really be called bad... granted, a few of them are [i]really[/i] bad.
-? Age gap... Depending on who you are and what you think of the setting, the age gap can be an issue for some romance paths (worst case is like 24 to 18, not outrageous but certainly questionable for modern standards).
+? Saves begin at the beginning of each turn only, essentially preventing save-scumming.
+? Japanese translation is decent, though that's coming from a non-native Japanese speaker.

Overall, I'd give this game a 9.5/10, with it very likely reaching 10/10 with updates to the localization and tooltips. Worth double its default price.  Get a copy for a friend who needs some wholesomeness in their life.

*Edit:  Added a couple more pros and cons for more clarity and some tips for new players.

This review is written from the point of view of someone who has loved the Princess Maker series since discovering Princess Maker 2 in early 2000s.

If you do not know this series you might be wondering why am I bringing up an entirely different game franchise when making a review about Volcano Princess.

You see, Volcano Princess is sorta a spiritual sequel to the Princess Maker series. A franchise of games where a father (you) obtains a daughter in some way and has to do his best to keep her safe and so that she grows up into a wonderful woman that will find her way through life.

I am not gonna go into too much detail about the mechanics and such as I feel figuring them out is half of the experience here but yes, this is basically Princess Maker 6.

Sadly similarly to Princess Maker series, it has a pretty bad English translation. If you cannot deal with that, then this might not be a game for you. It also has a rather strange saving system where you can only save at the start of the month. There is also a lot of RNG to combat, especially in the final dungeon where your daughter and her companions can just get stunned to death or instantly gibbed by certain enemies.

But, everything else is basically positive. When I played the game I have truly felt not just for my daughter Sylvie, but also for her father Fin (me) and all of the people of the Volcano Country. Where Princess Maker games kinda fail is secondary NPCs and Volcano Princess truly shines here. I will probably remember some of the people here forever, honestly.

Music is wonderful, only had one crash in an entire playthrough that I streamed over at my Twitch channel and generally the game plays well.

You can see the entire playthrough over at my Youtube channel, just look up Volcano Princess Fingusa and you should be able to see for yourself.

Thank you, developers. You have made a wonderful game and should be proud.

Only a few complaints! There are the occasional spelling errors, the kind that's expected with a translated game. Still, it would've been nice if they'd gotten someone else to give things a once-over. At least decide if Lon's name is Lon or Ron. 

I also wish you could go back and see the latest dialogue. I've accidentally skipped things I wanted to go back and read. 

They do a good job of walking you into how everything works for the most part. I didn't understand right away how combat was supposed to work because some attacks you click on and then select an enemy (even if it's an attack at all enemies) and some you click and they automatically do damage. 

None of the romanceable characters are too shallow or one-dimensional, but there is also room for improvement with them as well. Still, they're likeable, and I love seeing them interact with each other.

Huh.  I like this.  It's really kind good!  I'm also not sure exactly where to start.

Cons:  The English translation isn't the greatest and can lead to some mistakes when choosing dialogue lines.  The mini-games don't feel fully explained or were just awkward with no muscle memory to apply, and I whiiffed on most of them.  

Pros:  I usually play adult games and this came up on my feed and it is NOT an adult game (No I didn't expect it to be, but it was recommended based on my games played, which I thought was weird).  It's a cute child-raising game where you essentially level up the daughter and prepare her for life.   The artwork is great and the story was fairly engaging and cute.  There is a game + where you can buff up your stats to replay and get additional endings.

Word of warning, it's possible to achieve endless action points (the ability to do things in your turn), and when you purchased from the blacksmith dude... you build a relationship with him that ends up with the daughter marrying the son, at least in some scenarios, so word of warning.  I was disappointed when I discovered it and had no way to cut it off.

A key thing for ending are the attributes of stamina, mind, and charisma.   Lessons and a few other things help to build.  You also have other stats like strength, imagination, Emotional intelligence (I assume), and something else.   These determine how easy your lessons will be and are also gating elements for jobs and maybe other things every time you level those states, you get to upgrade your skills which makes the game easier.

I'd say a second play-through is required because I'll be surprised if someone plays with zero errors due to the translation.  Still, it is mostly understandable and enjoyable.

time played:  21 hours first play through although about three-four hours was building up cash/action points and massively building up stats as much as I could.  I still have a few more endings to do before my play-through, 

Value?:   I'd say yes either on sale or not.  I think it went on sale and that's why I pulled the trigger, but I'm not 100%.   Either way it is worth it.

So, do I recommend it?  Yes.   I purchased it on a whim because I wanted something different, and this worked well.  Check out other reviews and the images to make sure this type of game would appeal to you, but if you are interested based on my description of some gameplay elements (not going to cover all of them as there are quite a few and it depends on your paths) then I'd say to go for it.
