The elephant in the room here is the translation. It's Meh at best and outright gibberish at worst. 

There is a story and what I do understand is interesting. However, I get the feeling that there's a bunch of stuff I'm just missing? Unless you're meant to just piece things together from npc gossip. There's a few major plot points that I'm just not really sure what the relevance was but that might be because in my first playthrough, I didn't do any combat at all. 

Now, I know this review seems negative so far but here's why I still recommend this game: the mechanics. I really enjoy the combat mechanics. They took a hot moment for me to figure out but it was super satisfying when I did. The stat grinding is also something I really liked, and this IS a stat grinding game so if that's not something you're into, you're probably not going to enjoy this experience very much. The pretty graphics don't hurt either.

This might not be a perfect game but it's one that I liked enough to sink about 12 hours straight in a single day. My main complaint (besides the translation) is that I sure wish I knew which subject stats my lessons are leveling up.

I'll start with reasons not to buy first, then jump to reasons to buy afterwards.

The music is stock music taken from a sound library.

The art varies from very professional to quite bad, but you earn that good art. The bulk of your time is spent in really inconsistent play-dough looking characters and randomly one mode is pixel art.

The game was in no way designed for English letters. The translation is so bad, and some modes, like the aforementioned pixel art mode, take quite a lot of work to get to.

I feel kind of weird about some of the outfits you give to her, that provide necessary stat boosts.

The game is mostly menuing without animations. This is especially blatant in the very optional fighting sections of the game, where enemies have very simple silhouettes and pop in and out of existence.

Cutscenes with animation are very ugly. Kind of hard to tell what's actually going on in some cases, especially since they feature the primary conflict of the game very early on.

The good

You're going to need to finish quite a few playthroughs to get all the endings. My first time, my primary love interest turned into an eldrich horror that made my protagonist pass out and forget everything. Kind of an intense ending.

Lots of romance options for the MC, it's like Harvest Moon on fast forward.

Art can be very good when it wants to be, especially the ending, where judgy kid Rose tells you all about your failures.

Load times are very fast.

Lots of options for playthroughs.

It's... a game for people who want to play a game about raising a kid. It's not a game for everyone, and probably not a game that I'll revisit very often, but I played it and I don't necessarily regret it.
Very wholesome ^_^

The good: very charming and relaxing. Artwork is downright adorable. Fun experimenting with the different ways to raise your daughter.

The not as good: lots of progress breaking bugs. Of the ~2 hours on record for me so far, about 33% of that time has been spent replaying content after any number of errors force crash the game, break the UI so that menus can't be exited, and more.

The bottom line: there is a fun and charming game to be had here and with an introductory discount, it may be worthwhile. Be prepared to lose time, progress, and motivation to a number of technical issues beyond the player's control. Will update this review after more time/fixes have been applied.

EDIT: Update after a couple of days of waiting on bug fixes. I've now spent about 50% of my game time starting new games, losing progress, replaying content to try and get around the bugs, only to hit game breaking bugs again. I strongly recommend avoiding this game for the time being. It does not respect your time.

Absolutely adorable! Gameplay is a lot of fun and there's a lot to do. And the story is amazing I love it. I am a completionist and at the very least gonna get another 20 hours from this game so it's very worth the price. Also I do really appreciate that the game makes it really clear what you need to do to achieve certain endings, thats a problem I've had with other games. They also do a great job of making you feel like your choices matter. Plus mc is adorable 10000/10

There are a number of glitches that can anywhere between slightly annoying and soft-locking the game and since it's a small team the bug-fixing might take a bit. Translation is also pretty iffy but at least for me it never got in the way of understanding the story, most of it is words being translated differently in different spots, especially names (ex: Volcano year vs fire year or Rebressa vs Lebesa)

I personally think think the game is 100% worth it, but if you don't want to deal with the bugs/translation maybe wishlist it till some patches are done, or buy it while its on sale and let it sit in your library till one day you remember it exists

I LOVE MY DADDY!!!!

(Spoiler warning!)
Opening 
================================================================================================
My daughter was born on 23 April and named Jean. I must admit, this is truly a difficult start since early departure of my wife, but I must press on for the sake of our daughter, our dream. At her early age, we loved to went around town and tried everything we could do at that day. early morning activity was always go-to start for our plan. I knew, this wouldn’t lead to any further mastery in her future, nevertheless I wished she enjoyed everything that I could offer. 
As she growed up, she started to went around town and be a part of them. She truly one of the heart from the town, everyone is her friend. -heck, even i lost count, how many people has come to our house to see her (my guess is roughly 9, for romantic event). But it put ease on my mind since I got caught an unknown disease. At least, if it’s the will from the heaven to separate us on earth prematurely, she still had the town to rely on. But thanks to the heaven for he decided not to do so until the time.
My daughter wasn’t a champion but she was champion in my heart. She might not the best daughter in the world, but she’s the best for me and I hope the best for her. I’m proud of her, because she can be who she is and married to whom she loves.
Welp, actually, that’s my bad. I thought, it was better to had good term with his headmaster- Mr. Claude- so she wouldn’t have much trouble in school. Both of them took it too seriously, what a mess. At least, my advice, to cook first the ingredients, which come from her adventure, was a good idea. She becomes a good cooker and has her own restaurant.
And here I’m, on the first spring of this year without her, my wife reach home, which is truly a saving grace.
Also my transformation into a chicken is canceled, I don’t know why. I’m disappointed.

Review
================================================================================================
(Disclaimer) This’s my first steam review. It’s worth to take note that my gaming history mostly in fps genre and/or something relate to world war 2 but recently, I want to expend my horizon. So, take my opinion with a grain of salt. No, a lot of them, not just a grain.
Volcano Princess is a rising-“daughter” simulation with visual novel and rpg frame. The players are tasked to raise her daughter whatever they see suit for her. Your aim is her future career and fiancé (and yes, you can make your daughter marry to other daughter, I tried this to avoid “cucked” feeling but failing due to academic reason: pleasing the headmaster). How to do it? Raise those numbers, baby~. Each turn, the player has a number of action. It can be used to do activity and replenished in certain ways. To end turn, player “plan” study activity for the daughter.
There’s a lot of arts, ton of them, and there’re good but due to the variety accessories, I find it’s insufficient and bothering. But this flaw is ignorable.
The voice is limited to just reaction such as laughing, thinking, etc. There’s no text reading.
The music is okay at bringing the mood, but I ignored it most of the time.
The rising elements (or the gameplay) is okay. Most of the time, the players raise her daughter through town interaction and planning system. I find this system is boring, due to repetitiveness, since most daughter actions are dictated by player options directly (not through father as mediator) and counted in numbers. I prefer to say it as lack of surprise element because it’s sureness (the authority of player and the honesty of numbers). % RNG isn’t the surprise element I mean, but the turning events base on choice like “Disco Elysium” (unfair comparison, but that’s the best I have). 
The story is niche, classic fantasy and a little bit of plot. I’m not sure how the plot turns out since somehow, I managed to avoid by achieve true ending. The good part is the light-warm interaction between char’s family. Other interactions are sometimes ambiguous due to translation, but still readable by putting few logics. Too bad, I couldn’t focus the story much (mostly I skimmed) because I feel uncomfortable with the UI. It’s my problem since I have encounter many similar UI and I couldn’t do much about my concentration.
The game itself is a little bit buggy. I couldn’t open the letter from friends (or I stuck with letter in opened position) and few times my games force close by itself, I’m not sure why.
Final verdict, I with reluctant to pick unrecommended but due to major recommended review, I decide so. I couldn’t recommend this game to past-self because my gaming history. Nevertheless, it still a good experience although at certain point, I want to bash my head to my keyboard so badly. I highly recommend this game to people that love raising-simulation, romance, and/or “visual novel”. If you’re a casual, I recommend you to wait for a while because the bug problem and translation issue.
================================================================================================

I want to say I recommend this game, but there are so many bugs some of which game breaking. Can't read letters as there's no way to switch from the first letter in the stack or close the top window when you open them. Meaning you have to force quit the game. That's an entire feature of the game that not only doesn't work but literally breaks the game. Its also essentially auto save only. There is a save function, but when you load the game no matter where you saved you restart the entire day so you really can only save at the start of the day, where auto save saves your game already. To be fair the game tells you this when you save but if that was going to be the case the devs could have totally take the player save functionality out had the same result and fixed other bugs. If the player save feature is going to be there it should do something. Not sure if others had the issue, and at least this bug wasn't game breaking, but there is a stables race game bit to the game and it just doesn't function. You hover over the button to "Participate" and you can sit there and click all day but despite the button reacting visually to you hovering over and clicking it the button does nothing. Sometimes other clicks don't respond but if you wait a second and click again it suddenly works, and other times you click to read dialogue and it just skips two or three frames of dialogue or narrative and there's no way to go back so you just flat out miss it.
I feel like this could be a very good game especially for $10, but with all the bugs and some of them flat out game breaking along with sections/features of the game that just don't work at all this feels like a beta version or an early access game that you're paying for to do beta testing for free for the devs. Maybe there will be an update that fixes everything and I'll have to change this review, but until then I just can't recommend the game.

Overall, I really enjoy this game. If you liked My Life as a Teenage Exocolonist or Long Live the Queen you'll probably have a good time with this. It has a lot of content, I'd say I like it more that Long Live the Queen. Not nearly as much as My Life as a Teenage Exocolonist for a few reasons. There are several problems that you may or may not be able to overlook.

Most noticeably, the translations are CRUNCHY. It's not really a problem for most of the game, you can pretty easily get the gist of what was meant. Once you get in to later story stuff for the true ending it gets pretty difficult to understand, to the point that I'm wondering if there are some sequence breaks I found accidentally.

There are also two pretty severe and consistent game breaking bugs. First and foremost are the gift letters you receive. These will lock the game up every single time you try to open one. Fortunately they aren't really a necessary part of the game, they're mostly for flavor. Second is a save data corruption bug that can happen if you have cloud saves enabled. As of the version I'm playing (1.00.00 I think) the devs even have it in the announcements with instructions for how to turn off cloud saves. There are also a number of other bugs that are less consistent, e.g. I once had to force quit when I got stuck in the horse capturing event.

Fix for the letters bug:

Press windows key + R. Type in "steam://open/console"

download_depot 1669980 1669981 7590118745015040093

Then go to your steam folder > Steamapps > Content > app1669980 > depot1669981
And then copy the contents of that folder. Go to the game local files and paste the files you just copied. replace everything.

turn off the Steam Cloud function if it still not worked

This game is a lot of fun. Be a good dad and raise an awesome daughter. 

The game is similar to Long Live The Queen or My Life As A Teenage Exocolonist. 

You talk to people, give gifts, take classes, go on expeditions, farm, cook, work at a part time job, do alchemy, etc. You raise statistics through coursework, consuming certain farming outputs, consuming potions, buying outfits, or getting decorations for your house. Some combat specific stats can be raised through going on expeditions. Talking to characters you see on screen also grants a "perception" statistic / currency that is used when responding to letters you see if you have admirers, which can be gained from fame you get from attending balls or working as an actress, or from part time jobes at the bath with more sketchy jobs like card dealer for the mafia granting more admirers. The perception currency you get from talking to each character makes it worth while to talk to everyone and makes it so there are no useless character interactions in the game.

At the end of a playthrough, the person your daughter has the closest relationship with is the trigger for who your daughter marries as an adult. Your daughter may romance female characters if you to. Relationships with characters can be raised by chatting with them, giving them gifts, consulting them which also raises your statistics, challenging them to debates or duels, and taking them on dates. Dates so far seem completely platonic with some romantic undertones as nothing more lewd than handholding or hugging is shown (at least that I have seen in my 2 playthroughs so far).

As you play the game you will inevitably have accomplishments which are worth points at game end to make life the next time around easier. You can boost statistics, base relationship values with folks, boost fame, and get items for the next playthrough.

Like some other games in the genre, some of the "best" or possibly "true" endings are much easier to accomplish in your second playthrough with boosted statistics. There is some explanation on why the starting a new life narratively makes sense, but giving the specifics of why new game + is a thing in this setting would spoil the story. 

Current state, there are some typos, not enough to break the game, as the developer does not speak English natively. There are some bugs, that I ran into which caused me to need to restart the game. The developer has a discord and is actively working on fixing the reported bugs. 

I felt pretty good playing this game, I did not feel stressed out like I did in trying to get a good ending in Long Live the Queen. There are many endings you can get, and it is not the end of the world to get an average ending. Every playthrough can help you get achievements to boost your character in new game +. 

Oh, and the art is nice for the game. The seasonal changes in every single area of the game are nice.

Overall, highly recommend.

TLDR;
Great Princess Maker-esque (or Long Live the Queen) game despite some bugs and iffy english texts. 8/10

The good: There is a lot of things you can do, and choices to make that will give varying results without being too punishing. Aside from story related choices most mistakes can be fixed as long as you're not going for a perfect run.
A lot of short mini-games to keep it interesting without it being a chore, since obviously you'll be doing them more than once if you're aiming for a specific stat.
Although I've only reached one ending as of this review, the story and ending was nothing too far from what I would've expected from the choices I made.
The visuals are good, cute, and fitting.

The bad: At the time of the review, mainly the bugs and iffy english translations.
I ran into a few bugs but nothing terribly unavoidable or detrimental to the progression, but there were times where I needed to restart the game. At least the auto save is there in case you forget to manually save.
The text is mostly broken or have grammatical/spelling errors, but most are comprehensible to a point. This may bother some and break the immersion. Nothing was broken to the point of making a wrong choice during my first playthrough.

Some minor QoL functions are missing, such as text skipping but honestly since most texts are short it's not the end of the world.
Both manual and auto saves start at the beginning of the day, so there is no way to save right before choices. But again, the texts aren't long so it's not that difficult to go back to the same spot from the start of the day.

With my 30 hrs records, I guarantee this game for everyone.

Volcano Princess is more than their price. Even though the storylines are not that fascinating, I still love everything about Volcano Princess. (arts, friendly characters, atmosphere, sound, and my daughter absolutely) Thank you for making this priceless one.

P.S. Please decrease Claude's age. I love him and have married him many times, but his age makes me feel guilty for my daughter, and please don't increase the bishop's relationship too much when consulting.

Finally, I hope this game gets more love from players. Can I expect Season 2 or another Raised Baby Sims game from you? I want more! I'm looking forward to them!

总体来说是一部很不错的类《美少女梦工厂》系列的作品。85/100

优点：
1，美丽的动态2D背景、细致的CG作画、悠扬的场景BGM，为整个作品创造了特殊的独特氛围感；
2，游戏中设计了相当多数量的子系统，每一个子系统之下又能对应多种不同的反馈机制，无论是人际/探索/养成，皆有独到之处，与其它养成类游戏能拉开足够远的区分度；
3，世界观的设计能明显地看出制作组所花费的心力，游戏的仪轨涉及渗透到了方方面面，完全没有让人出戏的突兀感；
4，程序设计非常稳定，全程没有出现过一次崩溃、跳出、Bug事件。

缺点：
1，女儿在童年时期的时间过短，印象里只有短短数回合，女儿就会进入到青春期，这让玩家的心流节奏有些跟不上；
2，某一些子系统的数值平衡仍然需要进一步打磨，无论是探索战斗，还是人际关系，后期基本上都存在通用解法，多周目游玩不免缺乏足够的随机意外和惊喜；
3，大反派的人物弧光过于突兀，没有成功地说明反派为何之所以是反派，沦为一个脸谱化的存在，游戏最终幕的呈现节奏也过于赶工了。

This is the most blown away I've ever been at a game. I was expecting it to be some dumb poorly translated visual novel, and while it's still poorly translated (which only really makes it funnier, on top of a very funny game), what's mind blowing is HOW MUCH CONTENT THERE IS and also HOW GOOD IT ALL IS. I spent 11 hours on my first run, and noticed there are 58 ENDINGS, EVERY CHARACTER IS ROMANCEABLE (except 2, sorry dilf lovers) and there's a HADES-LIKE MIRROR OF DARKNESS SYSTEM. THIS GAME IS A ROGUELIKE VISUAL NOVEL????
I'm also blown away by how much heart it has. It really nails feeling both like raising a daughter and growing up yourself, as the game is split between playing as the father and as the daughter. The characters are ALL incredible, there isn't a single character I even thought was meh. The only problem I have with the story/characters is that there is SO MUCH that I can't possibly fit it all in one playthrough. Luckily, as I mentioned before, the new game plus allows you to start with a wide array of benefits like in Hades, which honestly is a very similar game.
As far as I can tell, there are 3 main "routes" you can take, which is basically strength, intelligience, or charisma. I went charisma on my first run, which meant I made a killing doing plays or working at the bathhouse, and can't wait to try the other two routes!
The combat is VERY good, which I was not expecting AT ALL. Like I said before, I did the charisma route, which meant my strength was lacking, but it was still really fun finding a combination of weapons and abilities that could let me triumph (burn is broken btw, it essentially gives you an extra attack worth of damage each turn, and it only accumulates)
I've been writing for too long. BUY THIS GAME, IT'S A STEAL.

Wanted to love the game, but the bugs that come w/ the english translation make it hard to play.  From game freezing after opening letters to game crashing randomly.  It makes it hard to enjoy along with the rough translation.

If you love Princess Maker 2, you'll adore this game. It takes what Princess Maker 2 did right and did it again.

More to do overall, I love the interactions and the endings, and you as the father have a larger part in the story.

Lots of endings (like PM2) with no set path to go through the game. Play as you want, help her make decisions and you're good to go.

Lots of unique characters to befriend. **Almost** everyone named in the game can be befriended.

Manual combat for explorations does get kinda lenghty, and I do wish there was an auto-battle option. Probably my least favorite thing in the game.
Only problem is there are translation issues with the interface. The story is translated very good, but the non story parts have some difficulty, like keeping names correct. You'll notice it. Hopefully they'll fix it in future patches as this game is beautiful.

Game is cute and has a lot of the old Princess Maker charm. But I would wait a little bit for the game to become more stable. Currently there are some game breaking bugs that prevent progress unless you play in Chinese, like getting letters from people. Also some possible save bugs if you play the demo or use the cloud saves.
Worth every penny.

Very cute, played through one time at about ~6 hours and absolutely cried at the end. I currently have no intention to play again because the game left me feeling wholly satisfied with how things wrapped up, and I personally believe that to be a big plus. Totally worth the $10.

Translation is rough in some spots but not bad enough to affect my enjoyment, and the only bug I encountered was the (often reported) issue where sometimes when you click on a letter the game softlocks. Luckily exiting the game, reloading the autosave at the start of the day, and simply ignoring the letters let me keep playing, but still an inconvenience that needs to be fixed.

All in all, lovely experience. It's very pretty and the different ways you can choose to progress kept things feeling fairly interesting. There's a lot of stuff and a lot of alternate endings, so if you're the kind of person who wants to grind those out you'll have a good time. I raised my daughter well and she grew up to be an upstanding young lady so I am content to put it  down with no regrets whatsoever. If you like these sorts of management games, especially if you're someone who came from Princess Maker, I think you'll like it a lot.

Finally, a Princess Maker game that is greatly improved! 

Highlights:

1.  No creepy relationship between father and daughter.  This is strictly you being an awesome Dad.
2.  Upon completion you get points that be used to permanently improve your stats for next game!  
3.  No useless walking in combat scenarios.
4.  Writing is translated, but generally good.  

If you liked any of the original Princess Maker games, this one is an absolute no-brainer to grab.  Fantastic game!

Overall pretty good game, superb art and I almost teared up at the familial r/s moments :      )

There comes a time in every man's life when he needs to take a look at himself in the mirror and wonder how exactly he reached such a place.
You have to truly ponder what decisions you have made along the way that brought you to the place of your final reckoning.

It is still unclear, even to me, why I purchased Volcano Princess.
There isn't anything wrong with it, with those nudity scenes throughout it's perfectly stellar. But when you look at it as a choice, you realize just how flawed you and the rest of humanity is.

What drove me to purchase such a game? What part of my soul felt so empty that I thought a virtual girl could fill it?
When I look into the boundless depths of my own loneliness I see a pool of reflection. My face isn't there, there is no face. There are only tears in that pool, tears of shame and loss and confusion.

If it were up to me again I know I would purchase it in a heartbeat, I know I would load it up and skip through the countless window prompts so I can have a single morsel of pornographic images which are readily available online.
Yet, despite the abundance of naked virtual women waiting in the digital sphere, I still chose to purchase this game and devote hours of my life to it. That time will never return to me, it is lost just like my soul and just like the time I fear I may never find it again.

There is something broken within me, something that desires sensation beyond my reach, something that whimpers every single night with the knowledge that there is no true Princess, it is a merely an illusion.
In my pursuit to find meaning in this long life, I sought the colorful lights and sounds of a world that only exists in a pop up window on my computer.

I am unsure what the moral of this review is, I am unsure about my place within the universe, all I know is that no amount of virtual girls can cure the vast rot that has overtaken me.

This game is amazing so far after 3 hours of playing.

It's Princess Maker 2 but bigger, better, with more activites, the world feels massive and it seems you have a degree of freedom that all "rise simulators" should aim for.

I remember when I played PM2 that you were kind of "forced" into warrior builds in order to go to the dungeon and it made seeking arts, literature paths boring and empty. This my friends is completely fixed in Volcano Princess.

Seems you can even romance girls and you are not locked into marrying your daugther to male (haven't reached the end game yet of course but the option seems to be there and the girls don't shy away of being "flirtious" with your daugther)

Also, the game has a loit of mini games, you are into dice gambling you have it, you are more into rhetorical debates you got it too, "mini" farming sim... it's there, cooking game... you got it, random "loot" grind... yup you guessed it it's there too.

9/10 If you ever played Princess Maker series or Romanesque Witch or any other "rising sim" it's a MUST BUY. 

The only thing I would like to be changed is that the achievements menu is kind of a HUGE spoiler, I would preffer it to be hidden with " ??????? " naming.
Raised my daughter to marrying the princess. 10/10 recommended

Wow.. This Game is like Long Live The Queen but way more fleshed out with so much to do! It has it all: turn based combat, relationship system, gambling, math, catching and taking care of horses, changeable outfits, fishing, and more!  There are some minor typos however the amount of content makes this so worth it. And only 10.99 ?? talk about a steal! The aspect of raising your daughter allows you to build a connection with the MC. The art is great, the characters are interesting its hard for me to pick a favorite. Even though one game play takes a lot of time to complete, I can see myself coming back to reach different endings and do things differently. Props to Egg Hatching! Well Done! I will be enjoying this game for a while :D
